channel.title: The Hot Can All Vinyl Power Hour
channel.description: A weekly hour long mix of Funk, Soul, R & B, Jazz, Disco, Afrobeat and whatever else we decide to throw in the mix.

item.title: The Hot Can All Vinyl Power Hour, episode 53: “The Facts From A To Z”
item.dc:creator: The Dirty Hunch
item.description: It’s the one year anniversary of The Hot Can All Vinyl Power and to commemorate the occasion we’re putting up our first episode dedicated to a single song: “Sunny” by Bobby Hebb. In addition to Hebb’s original (and two alternate … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
It’s the one year anniversary of The Hot Can All Vinyl Power and to commemorate the occasion we’re putting up our first episode dedicated to a single song: “Sunny” by Bobby Hebb. In addition to Hebb’s original (and two alternate versions Hebb cut in ’75!), we’ve put together a pretty diverse collection of covers ranging from mainstays of The Hot Can All Vinyl Power Hour to a few musicians who are being featured for the first time.

As one of the most frequently covered songs in popular music (second only to “Yesterday” perhaps?), “Sunny” has been a favorite of ours since the beginning. With it’s bouncing melody, optimistic lyrics and funky groove, what’s not to love?

Be sure to listen to this one for details on the first ever Hot Can prize giveaway! It’s our way of thanking you for listening to the show.

item.title: The Hot Can All Vinyl Power Hour, episode 43: “Hornets”
item.dc:creator: The Dirty Hunch
item.description: This week we wrap up our exploration of the music Herbie Hancock made with the Mwandishi Band. If you’re looking for more, dig up a copy of “Inside Out”, the second album from Eddie Henderson and most of the Mwandishi … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
This week we wrap up our exploration of the music Herbie Hancock made with the Mwandishi Band. If you’re looking for more, dig up a copy of “Inside Out”, the second album from Eddie Henderson and most of the Mwandishi Band. It was alluded to on the show but not mentioned by name. And be sure to check out Bob Gluck’s book “You’ll Know When You Get There” which tells the story of this great, oft-overlooked group.

item.title: The Hot Can All Vinyl Power Hour, episode 42: “You’ll Know When You Get There”
item.dc:creator: The Dirty Hunch
item.description: Watch out for this one. Inspired by Bob Gluck’s recent book “You’ll Know When You Get There”, we’re going to spend the next two episodes spinning some of the deepest, most out-there space funk from Herbie Hancock and the Mwandishi … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Watch out for this one. Inspired by Bob Gluck’s recent book “You’ll Know When You Get There”, we’re going to spend the next two episodes spinning some of the deepest, most out-there space funk from Herbie Hancock and the Mwandishi Band. We’ll trace the musical path that lead this group to the outer reaches of jazz group improvisation starting with Hancock’s work as a leader for Blue Note and as a sideman for Miles Davis and Freddie Hubbard and ending up at Head Hunters, one of the most commercially successful jazz albums of all time.

item.title: The Hot Can All Vinyl Power Hour, episode 28: “2300 Skiddoo”
item.dc:creator: The Dirty Hunch
item.description: Another episode that went long. That’s two in a row, but we haven’t heard any complaints. This week we step outside the usual Hot Can fare to listen to some of the most influential jazz pianists. The music spans the … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Another episode that went long. That’s two in a row, but we haven’t heard any complaints. This week we step outside the usual Hot Can fare to listen to some of the most influential jazz pianists. The music spans the late-50’s to the mid-80’s and includes some expected names and others maybe a bit less so. Lots of trios: Ahmad Jamal, Bill Evans, Herbie Nichols and Keith Jarrett plus their respective rhythm sections each offer a unique take on this pared down format.

intro: Booker T. and the MG’s, “Hip Hug-Her”, Hip Hug-Her; Stax, 1967

Lennie Tristano, “Turkish Mambo”, Requiem; Atlantic Records, 1981

The Bill Evans Trio, “Blue In Green”, Portrait In Jazz; Riverside, 1959

The Dave Brubeck Quartet, “World’s Fair”, Time Changes; Columbia Records, 1964

Herbie Nichols, “Blue Chopsticks”, The Third World*; Blue Note, 1975

Herbie Nichols, “The Lady Sings The Blues”, The Third World*; Blue Note, 1975

Herbie Nichols, “2300 Skiddoo”, The Third World*; Blue Note, 1975

Herbie Nichols, “The Spinning Song”, The Third World*; Blue Note, 1975

Andrew Hill, “One For One”, One For One; Blue Note, 1975

Keith Jarrett, “Autumn Leaves”, Standards Live; ECM, 1986

Thelonious Monk, “Straight, No Chaser”, Straight, No Chaser; Columbia Records

* – Linked to the the Allmusic entry for The Complete Blue Note Recordings instead which contains all of the tunes on The Third World plus alternate takes and has a more informative entry on Allmusic.

item.content:encoded:
This week we’ve got a couple of great tunes from Roberta Flack at either end of the show. In between is the usual mix of soul, funk and world rhythms.
